comments.commentBody:
" “He has these horrible views, but he’s sort of not vicious about them.” Sounds like St. Ronnie.

Always smile while you stab folks in the back. That way they will never notice that their environment, healthcare. and Social Security are being destroyed, not to mention civil rights.

Lordy, lordy, old Jeff was just fibbing when he swore under oath  he had no intent to assist the Russians in making sure their young, innocent hackers would grab/create mischief for Hillary while hacking into the DNC website. No God-fearing American would ever believe an innocent like Beloved-by-Pence Trumpy would even think about breaking the law, violating the Constitution or cheating just to win an election. As God is my witness.
Yes, this is right. We need to bring the issue of DT's tax returns up every time that we talk about this Soviet mess.
Richard prefers that the Democrats play the role of "loyal opposition", just like the Republicans did during the last six years of the Obama administration.
He's gotta go.  The Russia connection has got to be investigated.  With luck, we can throw the election results out.
No need to worry about "there's nothing there" in the Sessions' investigations.  Remember the threat of Nixon's impeachment was caused by clownish "plumbers", they were just the first to get caught.

Exactly what did you expect? Please read Scott Pruitt's emails. Our new EPA administrator colluded with the fossil fuel industry while attorney general of Oklahoma to the detriment of his state and country.  This is only the beginning.

Sage of Santa Cruz, I certainly agree with your priorities for the Democrats and with your assessment of this incompetent administration, but was the snarky "mistake on the lake" comment necessary?  This does not help our cause with people who live in the wonderful cities, towns, and rural communities of what coastals dismissively call "flyover" country.   (And have you ever been to Cleveland?  It's a fine place.)

it is sorta the gop thing.  did not john ashcroft in his advancement towards this hallowed position lose out an election to a DEAD man in his home state? so to keep him in employment the president didn't want to lose his legal brain.  am i just making up this memory?  nah, it happened.  gotta love those dead guys with the gall to win an election over a future attorney general of the  nation.  yeah the bar has been lowered for some time.  in my lifetime a position of great power used to hide in plain sight the ugly reality of our nation's sins.
Wake up.  It already smells, and there's more than one corpse in the Cabinet and Administration.  Our democracy is being dismantled now.
Looks like the Trump campaign operatives met more Russians than the 1980 U.S. hockey team

While what Jeff Sessions didn't disclose during his Senate confirmation hearings maybe troublesome, what is rather more curious and worrisome is reports of a Russian oligarch's plane landing at the same airport as where Trump landed more than a few times.

MSNBC's Rachel Maddow had a report on this yesterday. http://tinyurl.com/hvxjyyz

The oligarch involved, Dmitry Rybolovlev, it just so happens, bought a Florida mansion from Trump for more than twice what Trump paid for it. The landing of Trump's and Rybolovlev's planes at the same airport around the same time maybe coincidental.

But, the Ian Fleming quote, "Once is happenstance. Twice is coincidence. Three times is enemy action” may apply. We shall see.

Was the airport in Mina, Arkansas?

OK. That was frivolous. I agree with Ian Fleming. Let there be extended investigations.

I so wish all this was frivolous, LW. I'm afraid that is not so.

As for the airports, try this HuffPost link for the airports involved. http://tinyurl.com/hfr3to4

Oh, and Trump has been tweeting this morning about his phones being wiretapped by Obama.

I have no idea where this is all going, but my guess is all this will make WaterGate look like trivial stuff.

The Sessions-Russian involvement tale is a good one, but how about the story about how his successor in the Senate got his seat.  He was appointed by the Alabama governor, whom he was investigating for wrongdoing. Now that's some good stuff, Gail.

Bank of Cypress and the oligarchs, Comney and Trump's taxes need serious and aggressive investigation. The NYT and WAPO and a EU paper would do well to team up on pursuing these angles to elevate U.S. understanding of how bad "undue influence" is in this questionable presidency.  Perhaps then the GOP would have to protect the country, not their corporate funders and nonsensical Ayn Rand ideologues.

Gail,

On the quiz, there needs to be a "Choice E":

Send Sessions back to the future with Marty McFly so he can live in a 1955 America which is at least somewhat closer to the Stone Age era where he really belongs.
what was a Russian ambassador doing at the Republican convention and did anyone in the Press report on that or bother to find out? Shouldn't we have been informed in real time?

Ask yourself, if Hillary Clinton's attorney general was found lying under oath (about communicating with Russian officials during his conformation hearings, no less), how would the GOP respond?

Lock him up.

If any close to this had occurred under Obama or HRC, the Republicans would be howling.  Fox would be on it every second of every day.  There would be one investigation after the other.  Impeachment proceedings would already be underway.
It's absolutely exhausting trying to keep with this administration's lies. If we were in Japan, they would have fallen their swords on day one.

I don't understand why talking to Russians is so bad that people have to lie about it. It's  not like the Iran contra affair where the Reagan gang sold weapons to Iran not that long after the Iran hostage crisis so they could fight the Commies in Central America. Any way why are the Tumpie people acting so guilty and all? What has been traded to drop sanctions? And why doesn't Trump just tell Ukraine that it has to rejoin Russia. Both countries are pathetic places to live. Cold and broke.

Readily available statistics show that per capita income in the progressive states of Massachusetts. Oregon, Minnesota, New York, and Colorado exceed Wisconsin. Likewise, job growth rates since the Great Republican Recession are far greater in California, Oregon, Colorado, and New York. Perhaps you would do well to dig a little deeper before you take up your pen.

Also interesting to note that few Wisconsinites bothered to comment on your piece. In fact, the silence is deafening. Maybe they're busy signing another recall petition. Couldn't blame them.

Republicans must stand strong against protesting Democrats, spring of 2017?

I want to say outright I am largely ignorant of the U.S. Constitution. I am ignorant of all the machinery of government. I am ignorant of all the legal terms, the language of law which is rife in government. What I am not ignorant of is this: The Constitution and all the law speech over the history of the U.S. is something of a game equivalent to board games or sports rules or card games except not only has cheating never been prevented, the rules themselves have never been agreed upon and people interpret as they will, or make up rules or invent loopholes left and right. With the result that what has actually occurred in America today for all Constitution and rights is just vast and confusing administrative, bureaucratic, technocratic, law enforcement apparatus in which we all are entangled.

It all appears just an insidious game of snare the opponent. You get in your car and drive around and all the cars on the road cannot be distinguished between citizen and police or military or what have you (all the sunglasses, tinted windows, big official looking vehicles,--the authoritativeness of it all), and you step into any building or conversation associated with government and it is a maze of legalese/government speech in which no one can clearly state the rules much less assure integrity, so I fully expect both political parties to become more intimidating, official, Constitutional, "living and dead".

Mr Walker fails to mention the core issues that have contributed to the need for increased federal power over the economic, environmental, educational and social policies of our nation.

In our country, when state governments predominate over the federal, regional defacto oligarchies have instituted policies to repress major segments of our population. Sometimes the oppression has been used to the economic advantage of the oligarchies. The history of slavery is the obvious example but the Kansas trickle down debacle should not be ignored. Sometimes over religion; hello Utah. Sometimes over the right to unionize; read the history of the transportation industries.

If Mr Walker's view prevailed in 1957, Eisenhower would not have been able to use the power of the federal government in Little Rock nor would JFK have been able to make a difference when Maddox and Wallace blocked school doors.

The point is that our nation needs a consistent application of laws enabling liberties in our country if we are to remain a single nation. Only a strong federal government can make that happen.

Mr Walker, like his republican brethren, want to Balkanize this nation so that the power of their oligarchies remain unchallenged.

It's obvious that there was something going on between the Trump campaign and the Russian government. There is just too much smoke not to be a raging fire.

Perhaps they were negotiating a deal. Help Trump get elected and he will left the sanctions. Then Exxon could begin dealing in the Artic and make everyone rich (richer?). Maybe even make Trump's debt to Russian money men go away.

Unpatriotic? Even treasonous? Sure, but profitable. And isn't that all that counts in Trump world.

"States' Rights" is a term associated in recent history with segregation and the struggle for equality that continues to this day. States' Rights sound fine and noble in Governor Walker's words, but abrogating national standards and American ideals to impose a patchwork of regional biases and beliefs on American citizens is not a unifying principal that will "make America great again".

Without a strong federal government we would be a loose aggregation of states, unable to offer shared standards of equality and education to all our citizens, unable to mobilize vigorous response in the face of natural and man made catastrophes, unable to set standards that protect the states from environmental degradation by their neighbors, just to name a few drawbacks to a state centered American prospect. Mr. Walker cleaves to a self-centered conservative ideology that demeans the greatness of America, the very thing that has made America exceptional.
I thought they relieved themselves on a bed the Obamas had slept in. It was an act of disrespect if so.
